text:
Hey <@U025LU739QD> I previously had that challenge myself as the first 6 years of my career were full-time freelance.

The transition for me was extremely bumpy  however I managed to get into my current role as a Content Designer at eBay where I interface with 80+ partners on a weekly basis - and what's worked for me is that you look at what the company is looking to achieve and then take your portolio and explain how the projects relate to what you're doing.

I got into Airbnb because my manager liked my work for Iron Mountain and how I proposed taking a a similar strategy albeit for hospitality to grow their host base. And I got into the Payments division of eBay by calling out how my email campaigns for TEDxSan Francisco got us 800 paid attendees which sold us out - even though pretty much  at eBay, everything I write is combed through by lawyers.

The best advice I can give is to not be afraid to apply to roles because you're not a subject matter expert. What matters is that you're able to learn quickly and synththize information in the right manner. At least, that's worked except in some cases like legal and some science. Pharma marketing somewhat can be done without  a medical background.

Also, be prepared to answer lots of behavioral questions. When I hired on my team, we weren't just looking at the portfolio but also interpersonal skills, effectively handling feedback, ability to prioritize, etc.  -> That's really what stuck me when transitioning, however I leveraged my volunteer work with TEDx and onsite consulitng engagemetns to call out exmaples of that.

text:
Thanks for all the messages!

<@U016P3U4LJK> Sounds like that worked out well for you. I really like the idea of adding extra insight into the content I produce for clients to let them know I can offer more.

<@U0241GTJEDC> Many of the job posts I've been most interested in seem to be for newly created roles. It definitely seems like creating entirely new processes would be a big challenge (and responsibility). I'm glad it's working for you though!

<@U025R8X7F0C> So are you a kind of freelance content manager? That interesting as I definitely like the freedom and security of having multiple clients.

<@U0107Q25BRT> That makes a lot of sense. I'm trying to do something similar with how I present my projects when applying for work. I guess that even showing an understanding of how work fits into the overall strategy will help a bit.

elements.text: Sounds like that worked out well for you. I really like the idea of adding extra insight into the content I produce for clients to let them know I can offer more.

Many of the job posts I've been most interested in seem to be for newly created roles. It definitely seems like creating entirely new processes would be a big challenge (and responsibility). I'm glad it's working for you though!
So are you a kind of freelance content manager? That interesting as I definitely like the freedom and security of having multiple clients.

That makes a lot of sense. I'm trying to do something similar with how I present my projects when applying for work. I guess that even showing an understanding of how work fits into the overall strategy will help a bit.
